pros: Broward College works hard to develop a positive work culture and staff.
cons: There is so much to learn about the school and all the information could be overwhelming.

pros: Coworkers are pretty easy to get along with, schedule is pretty unchanging.
cons: They will get you in the door promising higher pay, but once you accept the job and leave your current one they tell you that the pay is actually much lower. If you advance to a higher position or another department, the pay is still much lower than average/ other higher education employers. They give you annual evaluations and goals to meet, but never a raise. You might get lucky and they will throw you a couple hundred bonus chump change, but it fluctuates based on how management is feeling. They will force you to take their health insurance plan, or require you to show them proof that you have it elsewhere in order to decline. The coworkers that are in the same boat as you, are usually great to work with because they all share the same complaints with working for BC. Unfortunately there is a Clique culture and the upper management have favorites, and the rest cannot even use vacation time without reprimand. Don't bother asking for schedule accommodations, people that have been there for 10+ years have been let go for those requests. This place used to be great, but has become a revolving door for employees. If you are dealing with irate students, too bad. They don't care for your safety. They only care about appearances. They have literally had police on campus because a student announced they had a gun, but still decided to tell employees that they had to stay on campus and continue working. They didn't send out a picture or description of the student or even allow staff to go home, and shut down the campus until the student was detained. Even if you have issues with another employee, they only care if you actually get assaulted. If you have a question and need to speak with your supervisor, they will literally leave you on read, and get around to you later, most of the time it's days later. This happens 100% of the time. Meanwhile management will share vacation photos to lavish places that you could never afford because they won't pay you enough, yet rub it in your face they line their own pockets with six figures. The workload never ends and they will make sure they have extra "projects" to keep you busy if the micro-management doesn't think your working hard enough for the chump change they give you for pay. As for working for higher education, you might assume they value employees that want to obtain degrees while working at BC, but they say your work comes first, and you cannot take classes if it interferes with your work schedule. Remember, they won't accommodate, even if they can - they choose not to. If it's your birthday or special occasion they will tell you happy birthday through chat, but if it's a supervisors birthday/ wedding anniversary/ birth of their cousin, they will literally ask you to pitch in money to send gifts/ flowers/ etc. Management will only speak to you because they are obligated to say hi when passing by, or you've done something to upset them/ not working hard enough. They will also pit you against other coworkers and ask you to snitch on them if they are late/ not working. Unless that person is part of the clique and is allowed to get away with anything. When a supervisor sees that you have made a mistake, they will announce it in a meeting - in a way that makes it seem like you're incompetent and you're a child. They will also say that they don't have enough money in the budget for basic office supplies, yet buy the entire office god-awful (cheaply made) blazers that you cannot wear elsewhere because they printed your name on the front. They also force you to share desks with other employees, as well as double check your coworkers work. If you recently worked with someone who had COVID at the time and you might have been infected, they won't tell you. They won't even do the courtesy of saying go get tested just in case. From the outside looking in, it's great.

pros: Promotion from within, pending having amicable relationships with other supervisors. Professional Development opportunities are always available and keep staff up to date on latest software and technological advances in the college.
cons: Micro-politics dictate pay, promotion, and treatment. Leadership team is known for appointing family members and unqualified staff. Promotion is also based on who you know, not what you know. Raises generally go to newer staff while older staff will easily go years without increase (noted in various departments across the many campuses). A lot of the systems in place, soft/firmware and workflow, are outdated and useless, but the leadership staff does not like changes to the internal systems. Proposed minor changes to workflow usually take 5+ years, or are implements without testing leading to calamity. Compensation often does not match the presumed work load. Load of two or more people will easily be piled on one person in order to avoid hiring someone else immediately. Work usually stays with said person after a hire is made as well (noted across the college).  Leadership often does not relate to staff in the lower tiers and do not innately understand the positions they are supervising.

review_title: A College with Great Potential that Needs to Respect and Appreciate its Employees
pros: The people at the department level are wonderful.  My immediate supervisor couldn't be nicer or more supportive.  My fellow colleagues are also wonderful.
cons: The upper administration is heavy into politics and trying to please a micromanaging Board of Trustees.  As a result, because of their fear of losing their jobs, the upper administration doesn't do what is best for the Faculty and staff below them.  They do not support pay raises that try to catch up to the increase in the cost of living in South Florida.  They also claim there is no money for pay raises, but if you look at all the new construction going up on the campuses, the average person might disagree.

job_title: Administrative Specialist II in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Student events, Professional Development day, paid time off (vacation, personal, sick), off when the college closes for holidays and breaks.
cons: Low salary, over worked, lack of customer service, no accountability from upper management, promotions are minimum because it's about who you know, not the skills you posses.

review_title: Ok experience, but it could have been better.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Great location. Opportunity to get to know a lot of different people from different backgrounds. Opportunity to network.
cons: The positions are limited and there is no clear career path in which one could grow in.  This is why there is a big turnover for the Administrative positions.  You are not paid very well, most of the time is minimum wage.  There is only one person doing a lot of different jobs all at once. If you wish to work here, you have to be willing to multitask but make sure you don't drop the ball.

review_title: If you want to encounter glass ceilings, red tape, and in-office discrimination, work at Broward College!
job_title: Manager of Employee Wellness in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Experience in "higher education". Living in South Florida. The close proximity to the ocean. Partial tuition reimbursement. Knowing where you don't want to work.
cons: The culture at Broward College is to distrust, blame, produce as little work as possible, and micromanage high-performing employees. High-performing employees are not challenged nor rewarded and are somewhat pushed out while low-performing employees are promoted and protected because of whom they know or are best friends with. Unfortunately, if Broward College continues to operate in this manner not only will every single employee suffer but the students they serve will suffer as well. I hope that Broward College gets their act together for the sake of calling themselves "higher education".

pros: Even the President doesn't have a Ph.D. so really easy school!  No standards and very low expectations.
cons:
For tenure-track faculty, after your probationary period is over, BC does not have to tell you why you are not getting tenure. Be sure and read the Collective Bargaining contract. It states "During the probationary period, the Faculty member shall be on annual contact on a year to year basis. Such annual contract shall not create the expectancy of employment beyond the term of the contract nor shall non-renewal of the annual contract entitle the Faculty member to a hearing on the reasons for non-renewal. (Page 2 of the Employee Handbook). 

If someone doesn't like you in the department (like jealousy for example), you are screwed.  BC is the type of place where the covered wagons pull in, and shoot in. Buyer beware!

review_title: A good place to get experience and affect lives, but career options are limited
pros:
Employees and co-workers are generally very friendly and you get the chance to make a difference in the lives of many students.

The Board of Trustees holds hearings for students, staff and faculty throughout the year to voice their concerns.
cons:
There aren't many kinds of jobs available if you're not an educator or willing to do technical or clerical support work.

If you are a part-time employee, you have no guarantee of future work within the college if and when there are funding cuts, even if you have been an employee for a long time.

Information is difficult to find on your own if you're not already knowledgeable or in the right department. The website is terrible and has been for many years, even after recent changes.

review_title: Great job, if you like low pay and no security
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros:
Students are wonderful
Supportive colleagues  in the department
Autonomy
cons:
No job security.
No benefits.
No raises in 5 years.
When the AD left, a former teacher was promoted and directly lied about opportunities for classes.
Adjuncts were told there were not enough classes to go around because of enrollment, but they held 3 recruiting events and hired a ton of new adjuncts, putting decade-long employees with excellent student reviews on standby.
After an entire year of not getting responses from the AD or her assistants, we were all fired.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Students excited to learn and want you to get them involved.  Good opportunity for continuing-education pleasant campuses with good weather year round.
cons: Limited opportunity to career growth and constant focus on being number 1 takes away from doing the right thing for students. Losing good professors because of politics and keeping hard working employees as part time hurts in the long run.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Coral Springs, FL
pros: Very relaxed corporate culture.   Lots of time off and great for families.
cons: Very much a secretive culture.   lots of retaliation if you attempt to rock the boat.  Little or no leadership in some areas.  Very little direction in the workplace.   If you ask a different person on what to do - you'll get a different answer.

pros: One of the best rewards of working for BC is that you have a big family to turn too when needed. You meet individuals from diverse backgrounds and somehow you have immediate family members. Serving this institution for 13 years has allowed to give back to our new students and community on various levels.
cons: Not all departments are able to participate in workshops or activities due to the limited staffing in various areas. Everyone should be able to experience the BC family atmosphere to promote comradery.

job_title: Senkior Executive Assistant in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Opportunity to work with some great people that are working hard to assist students to complete their education.  It was a pleasure to interact with students, faculty and peers that displayed a passion for what they do.
cons: Hiring process is very long which becomes discouraging to applicants.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Working with the students is wonderful! There is such a diverse population of students and employees.  If you love helping people and are interested in helping them succeed in higher education this place is for you.
cons: Higher level management is clueless about the resources that students need. Management has their own agendas and is not always in the best interest of the students!

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Broward College has been a superior institution in which to work for the last eighteen years. My colleagues are exceptional, and my students are wonderful.  I highly recommend BC for new professors who would like to be a part of a high-ranking, on the cutting-edge state college. The students, faculty, leadership, professional staff at BC work hard to make it a special place to work.
cons: None of substance beyond the regular and expected challenges of a public state college.

job_title: Project Manager in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: You will learn a lot. Like any other job there is plenty to do. Plus, there are co-workers that will help our with you and help you grow.
cons: There are some that will take credit of your work and gossip is everywhere. I suggest you don't advertise yourself. Just keep it brief and professional.

job_title: Marine Production Support Technician in Plantation, FL
pros: Time off at Christmas and Spring Break They don't pay overtime, so you are not asked to stay late.
cons: Cutting positions and pilling up those task on other employees that are still working there. Always under staffed, and have had major walkouts of students. Number 1 reason is Instructors have no experience in the field that they are teaching.

job_title: Senior Specialist, Campus Technology in Davie, FL
pros: The time off, can't beat a week off during spring break and two weeks off at Christmas, plus you earn 12 sick days and 12 vacation days per year.
cons: Low pay, I could probably make $20,000 more at a private company.

job_title: Higher Education Administration in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The benefits, maybe, it's changed over the years the but the ends don't justify the means. What's the point of have 24 days PTO if they will subject you to ridicule and retaliation for using it?
cons: Just when you thought Trump Administration couldn't have been beyond ridiculous, welcome to Broward College! Let me start off by saying that I've worked here for 5+ years in various departments and all have been a rude awakening. The saying around is: "what's good for the goose, is not good for the gander." Be ready to deal with hypocrisy and being told to do one thing while senior management does another. Human Resources protects the managers and adhere to all of their false tales while the employees are subjected to whatever may come their way. The pay is the most absurd thing you'll encounter, there are employees with Master degrees getting paid $30-40k! If you happen to get employed under the union then that may be your saving grace, otherwise BC adheres to the "at will" policy and treat you accordingly if you don't play the political game well or disliked. And beware of the "fake" kindness, they will try to get close to you, learn your mannerism and personal information and then use it against you... It's a true battleground so strap up! If you are a true believer of your craft and know your worth, go elsewhere where they'll pay and appreciate what you bring to the table.

job_title: Student Worker in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros: They Respect your School Schedule and work around your hours. I think that's just because your Work Study.
cons: There's too much drama amongst employees that it almost makes you feel like your in high school all over again.

review_title: Decent organization but much more could be done for the students and the employees
job_title: Program Coordinator in Pembroke Pines, FL
pros: They really advertised student success and are trying to achieve that
cons: If you are not part of a specific click you will not be given a chance to grow

cons: The paycheck didn't arrive until the entire 6-week session was over. That was the only negative I found.

cons: Executive leadership may gain more insight of the campus culture by communicating more with the Professional Technical Staff and Faculty.

review_title: Smooth journey. Lots of social and customer interaction, but very low ceilings.

cons: This institution is not supportive of faculty.....ore interested in their numbers and profit. Faculty are attacked in classrooms by students and nothing is done to the student. Administration states they are giving student second chance( some case 4th chance) with certain parameters that doesn't seem to phase student. Also, support staff are afraid to be fired.

review_title: A great place to get an education, as well as entry into the workforce.
pros: Very dynamic and fun, so the school never feels like it gets stagnant.
cons: Departments and areas tend to feel like they all work independently of each other.

pros: Free education and beautiful Davie, FL campus (Central  Campus). Great team of employees on Central Campus!
